elements.content: Three new metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are formed from the reaction of zinc with 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (H3-5-hip) with a range of additives in dimethylformamide (DMF). The additives include water, pyridine, and [Me n NH4–n ]Cl (n = 0–4) and, through hydrogen bonding, have a marked effect on the formation and phase of any resultant MOF, often in a narrow range of substoichiometric concentrations. The three MOFs, [Me2NH2][Zn2(5-hip)(H-5-hip)(H2O)]·3.25DMF (1), α-[Me2NH2]2[Zn2(5-hip)2]·2DMF (2), and [Me2NH2][Me4N]2[Zn4(5-hip)2(H-5-hip2.5)]·3DMF (3), have solvent-accessible pores, and the flexibility of the MOFs allows relaxation from a porous state to minimize the void space on desolvation. Topological analysis of the frameworks reveals two previously unrecorded MOF topologies. Compounds 2 and 3 are fluorescent, while this property is absent in compound 1. We also present a revised structure for the closely related β-[Me2NH2]2[Zn2(5-hip)2]·2DMF (4).

The additives include water, pyridine, and [Me n NH4-n ]Cl (n = 0-4) and, through hydrogen bonding, have a marked effect on the formation and phase of any resultant MOF, often in a narrow range of substoichiometric concentrations. The three MOFs, [Me2NH2][Zn2(5-hip)(H-5-hip)(H2O)]⋅3.25DMF (1), α-[Me2NH2]2[Zn2(5-hip)2]⋅2DMF (2), and [Me2NH2][Me4N]2[Zn4(5-hip)2(H-5-hip2.5)]⋅3DMF (3), have solvent-accessible pores, and the flexibility of the MOFs allows relaxation from a porous state to minimize the void space on desolvation. Topological analysis of the frameworks reveals two previously unrecorded MOF topologies. Compounds 2 and 3 are fluorescent, while this property is absent in compound 1. We also present a revised structure for the closely related β-[Me2NH2]2[Zn2(5-hip)2]⋅2DMF (4).

elements.content: Structure-directing ammonium cations play an important role in the formation and structural properties of a range of four zinc MOFs containing 5-hydroxyisophthalate. Each MOF contains the same [(Ph−O)−(Zn2)−(OOC−Ph)] secondary building unit to produce different structures dependent on the structure-directing agents added to the synthetic mixture.
elements.clean_text: Structure-directing ammonium cations play an important role in the formation and structural properties of a range of four zinc MOFs containing 5-hydroxyisophthalate. Each MOF contains the same [(Ph-O)-(Zn2)-(OOC-Ph)] secondary building unit to produce different structures dependent on the structure-directing agents added to the synthetic mixture.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are an intensely researched field of inorganic and materials chemistry that is beginning to mature from an initial phase of discovery toward to the creation of functional materials through utilization of their remarkable range of properties. As such, many researchers now look to create MOFs with multiple properties in order to probe the interplay between different facets of their multifunctionality, leading to porous frameworks with enhanced features for catalysis, molecular magnetism, and biological applications. Another potential area in which the host–guest chemistry of MOFs can interact with additional properties is in the area of sensing where adsorbed species may interact with the framework to produce colorimetric or fluorescent changes as a means of adsorbate detection. Fluorescence in MOFs generally takes one of two forms, either metal centered, such as the lanthanides, or ligand centered, through the immobilization of fluorescent ligands within the MOF.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are an intensely researched field of inorganic and materials chemistry that is beginning to mature from an initial phase of discovery toward to the creation of functional materials through utilization of their remarkable range of properties. As such, many researchers now look to create MOFs with multiple properties in order to probe the interplay between different facets of their multifunctionality, leading to porous frameworks with enhanced features for catalysis, molecular magnetism, and biological applications. Another potential area in which the host-guest chemistry of MOFs can interact with additional properties is in the area of sensing where adsorbed species may interact with the framework to produce colorimetric or fluorescent changes as a means of adsorbate detection. Fluorescence in MOFs generally takes one of two forms, either metal centered, such as the lanthanides, or ligand centered, through the immobilization of fluorescent ligands within the MOF.

elements.content: We have recently investigated the role of the metal nodes in a series of alkaline earth MOFs in the deactivation of ligand fluorescence and have made recent efforts to produce new porous framework materials consisting of colorless diamagnetic metal ions with fluorescent bridging ligands.
elements.clean_text: We have recently investigated the role of the metal nodes in a series of alkaline earth MOFs in the deactivation of ligand fluorescence and have made recent efforts to produce new porous framework materials consisting of colorless diamagnetic metal ions with fluorescent bridging ligands.

elements.content: The rational design of any new MOF usually includes consideration of the use of secondary building units (SBUs), which are the main tool in the structure direction of MOFs with specified structural motifs. While many SBUs are reliably formed in situ for given ligand and metal groups (e.g., the Zn4O cluster in the IRMOF family), different bridging ligands can give rise to other functional structural units if they contain competing coordinating sites or structure-directing modes.
elements.clean_text: The rational design of any new MOF usually includes consideration of the use of secondary building units (SBUs), which are the main tool in the structure direction of MOFs with specified structural motifs. While many SBUs are reliably formed in situ for given ligand and metal groups (e.g., the Zn4O cluster in the IRMOF family), different bridging ligands can give rise to other functional structural units if they contain competing coordinating sites or structure-directing modes.

elements.content: Another factor in the formation of MOF architectures is the role of hydrogen bonding, which may affect the form and formation of a MOF. Zn–O bonds in MOFs such as MOF-5 are considerably stronger than hydrogen bond interactions between O–H···O and N–H···O groups (90 kJ mol–1 against ∼8–21 kJ mol–1). As such, hydrogen-bonding is not likely to prevent the formation of Zn–O bonds. However, the difference in energy between different Zn-carboxylate bonding modes is comparable to the energy of the above hydrogen bonds; thus hydrogen bonding is likely to have a major role in the structure of MOFs at some point of formation, as recently demonstrated by Forgan et al.
elements.clean_text: Another factor in the formation of MOF architectures is the role of hydrogen bonding, which may affect the form and formation of a MOF. Zn-O bonds in MOFs such as MOF-5 are considerably stronger than hydrogen bond interactions between O-H⋅⋅⋅O and N-H⋅⋅⋅O groups (90 kJ mol-1 against ~8-21 kJ mol-1). As such, hydrogen-bonding is not likely to prevent the formation of Zn-O bonds. However, the difference in energy between different Zn-carboxylate bonding modes is comparable to the energy of the above hydrogen bonds; thus hydrogen bonding is likely to have a major role in the structure of MOFs at some point of formation, as recently demonstrated by Forgan et al.

elements.content: 5-Hydroxyisophthalic acid (H3-5-hip, Scheme ) presents an excellent opportunity to introduce a nonlinear dicarboxylate with a possible third coordination site while incorporating fluorescent properties. In order to avoid quenching or interfering with the fluorescent properties of the ligand, a diamagnetic, colorless metal ion was chosen, for which zinc provided the best chance of producing new materials on account of its flexible coordination preferences. To increase the potential of the formation of new frameworks, a range of amines, water, and ammonium cation additives were tested as structure-directing agents in the synthesis of MOFs: H2O, NH4Cl, MeNH3Cl, Me2NH2Cl, Me3NHCl, Me4NCl and pyridine. The aim is to either provide different hydrogen-bond potential by alternating the number of N–H bonds or alter the pH of the reaction solution to vary the hydrogen bond acceptors by introducing nitrogen lone pairs from pyridine.

To increase the potential of the formation of new frameworks, a range of amines, water, and ammonium cation additives were tested as structure-directing agents in the synthesis of MOFs: H2O, NH4Cl, MeNH3Cl, Me2NH2Cl, Me3NHCl, Me4NCl and pyridine. The aim is to either provide different hydrogen-bond potential by alternating the number of N-H bonds or alter the pH of the reaction solution to vary the hydrogen bond acceptors by introducing nitrogen lone pairs from pyridine.

elements.content: All reagents were used as received without further purification. DMF was Laboratory Reagent grade supplied by Fisher Scientific with a stated water content of <0.2%. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data was collected at 100 K on a Rigaku AFC12 goniometer equipped with an enhanced sensitivity (HG) Saturn 724+ detector mounted at the window of an FR-E+ Superbright Mo Kα rotating anode generator (λ = 0.71075 Å) with HF or VHF varimax optics. Unit cell parameters were refined against all data, and an empircal absorption correction was applied in Crystal Clear. All structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-2013 and refined on F O 2 by SHELXL-2013 in the WINGX environment. All hydrogen atoms were added in calculated positions and refined in riding mode on the parent atom. Diffuse solvent electron density was analyzed and accounted for in SQUEEZE. Each phenyl ring is prefixed with a number for easy identification (e.g., C21 is ring 2). Further description of the crystallographic issues in compounds 2 and 3 are detailed below. Powder X-ray diffraction was carried out using a Bruker D2 Phaser with a Lynxeye detector and Cu Kα radiation (1.5405 Å). Le Bail profile fits on powder X-ray data were performed in Rietica to ensure sample purity. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using a PerkinElmer STA6000 simultaneous thermal analyzer, and the sample was heated from room temperature to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C min–1 under an O2 atmosphere. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were collected using a Micromeritics 3-Flex at 77 K. Samples were prepared by washing with 3 × 5 mL of clean DMF, exchanging with 3 × 5 mL of CHCl3, and evacuating at either 100 or 25 °C. Fluorometry was carried out on an Agilent Technologies Cary Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer in 1 × 10–5 M DMF solution or using a homemade quartz solid-state sample holder with an incidence angle of ∼110° between the plane of the sample and the path of the excitation beam. UV–vis measurements were performed on a Shimadzu UV-2700 in 1 × 10–5 M DMF solution or a Shimadzu ISR2600 integration sphere for solid samples on a BaSO4 support. Infrared spectra were recorded on a Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS10 spectrometer with Smart ITR accessory between 400 and 4000 cm–1.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Experimental Methods

All reagents were used as received without further purification. DMF was Laboratory Reagent grade supplied by Fisher Scientific with a stated water content of <0.2%. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data was collected at 100 K on a Rigaku AFC12 goniometer equipped with an enhanced sensitivity (HG) Saturn 724+ detector mounted at the window of an FR-E+ Superbright Mo Kα rotating anode generator (λ = 0.71075 Å) with HF or VHF varimax optics. Unit cell parameters were refined against all data, and an empircal absorption correction was applied in Crystal Clear. All structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-2013 and refined on F O 2 by SHELXL-2013 in the WINGX environment. All hydrogen atoms were added in calculated positions and refined in riding mode on the parent atom. Diffuse solvent electron density was analyzed and accounted for in SQUEEZE. Each phenyl ring is prefixed with a number for easy identification (e.g., C21 is ring 2). Further description of the crystallographic issues in compounds 2 and 3 are detailed below. Powder X-ray diffraction was carried out using a Bruker D2 Phaser with a Lynxeye detector and Cu Kα radiation (1.5405 Å). Le Bail profile fits on powder X-ray data were performed in Rietica to ensure sample purity. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using a PerkinElmer STA6000 simultaneous thermal analyzer, and the sample was heated from room temperature to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C min-1 under an O2 atmosphere. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were collected using a Micromeritics 3-Flex at 77 K. Samples were prepared by washing with 3 × 5 mL of clean DMF, exchanging with 3 × 5 mL of CHCl3, and evacuating at either 100 or 25 °C. Fluorometry was carried out on an Agilent Technologies Cary Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer in 1 × 10-5 M DMF solution or using a homemade quartz solid-state sample holder with an incidence angle of ~110° between the plane of the sample and the path of the excitation beam. UV-vis measurements were performed on a Shimadzu UV-2700 in 1 × 10-5 M DMF solution or a Shimadzu ISR2600 integration sphere for solid samples on a BaSO4 support. Infrared spectra were recorded on a Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS10 spectrometer with Smart ITR accessory between 400 and 4000 cm-1.

elements.content: DMF solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (4.0 mL, 0.1 M), DMF solution of H3-5-hip (4.0 mL, 0.1 M), and DMF solution of Me3NHCl (2.0 mL, 0.1 M) with 5 μL of H2O added per milliliter of DMF were heated to 120 °C in a scintillation vial for 72 h. Pale yellow block crystals of 1 were formed with a yield of 25 mg (16% relative to Zn).

elements.content: DMF solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (4.0 mL, 0.1 M), DMF solution of H3-5-hip (4.0 mL, 0.1 M), 60 μL (0.77 mmol) of pyridine, and 300 μL of distilled water (16.67 mmol) were heated as above, yielding 119 mg of yellow block crystals (82% relative to Zn). Synthesis without pyridine produces 116 mg of 2 but with a small impurity fraction of 1.

elements.content:
Compound 4 was synthesized in the same way as compound 2 but heated to 130 °C for 72 h to yield white plate crystals of the compound reported in ref .

Results and DiscussionCrystal Structures

Compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c (Table ) and consists of two zinc atoms, one monoprotonated 5-hip dianion, one unprotonated 5-hip trianion, one water molecule, and one dimethylammonium ([Me2NH2 +]) cation (Figure ). The coordination sphere of the two Zn atoms consists solely of oxygen atoms from carboxylates, phenoxides, and water so that Zn1 is approximately tetrahedral and Zn2 is almost exactly halfway between square pyramidal (sbp) and trigonal bipyramidal (tbp) with τ = 0.51 where τ = (β – α/60) with τ = 0 being sbp and τ = 1 being tbp (see Scheme ).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of β-[Me2NH2]2[Zn2(5-hip)2]⋅2DMF, 4 

Compound 4 was synthesized in the same way as compound 2 but heated to 130 °C for 72 h to yield white plate crystals of the compound reported in ref .

Results and Discussion

Crystal Structures

Compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c (Table ) and consists of two zinc atoms, one monoprotonated 5-hip dianion, one unprotonated 5-hip trianion, one water molecule, and one dimethylammonium ([Me2NH2 +]) cation (Figure ). The coordination sphere of the two Zn atoms consists solely of oxygen atoms from carboxylates, phenoxides, and water so that Zn1 is approximately tetrahedral and Zn2 is almost exactly halfway between square pyramidal (sbp) and trigonal bipyramidal (tbp) with τ = 0.51 where τ = (β - α/60) with τ = 0 being sbp and τ = 1 being tbp (see Scheme ).

elements.content: The Zn atoms are bridged by the phenoxide of ligand 1 and a carboxylate of ligand 2 to form the SBU shown in Scheme . Ring 2 is disordered over two positions, and in each the hydroxyl group hydrogen bonds to another disordered ring 2. The anionic 3D framework is constructed by connecting the (PhO)Zn2(PhCOO) SBUs across the non-SBU carboxylates. Channels in the structure are formed in the (−110) direction (Figure ) with an approximate pore width of 3 Å with water present and 4.1 Å without. The [Me2NH2]+ cations hydrogen bond to the framework walls with methyl groups extending into the pores. The remaining void volume is occupied by DMF solvent molecules. SQUEEZE analysis indicates the presence of 3.25 molecules of DMF per formula unit, three of which could be seen during assignment of the structure of 1 but were unstable on refinement. The 5-hip ligands are 2- or 3-connected, while the dimer is 5-connected, leading to an hml1 (42.63.85)(42.6) topology, which is previously unreported to the best of our knowledge.

elements.content: Compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c, and the asymmetric unit (Figure ) consists of two zinc atoms, two triply deprotonated 5-hip molecules, and two [Me2NH2 +] cations. The Zn atoms are each coordinated by four oxygen atoms in a near-tetrahedral configuration with the O21 phenoxyl and O12–C17–O13 carboxylate forming the motif seen in Scheme . The remaining coordinating oxygen atoms are from 5-hip molecules outside of the asymmetric unit, building up the three-dimensional MOF structure. This MOF is anionic with a charge of 2– per [Zn2(5-hip)2] formula unit, and charge balancing is provided by two [Me2NH2 +] cations that hydrogen bond to the framework (Table S4, ) as observed for 1.

elements.content: Compound 2 contains 2.5 Å diameter one-dimensional pores running in the (−101) direction, which contain the cations and DMF solvent molecules (Figure ). SQUEEZE analysis indicates a void space of 639 Å3 and the presence of 329 electrons per unit cell, equivalent to eight DMF molecules, giving two per formula unit. As with 1, this extra-framework DMF could be faintly seen in Fourier difference maps but was unstable on refinement. The crystals of 2 are pseudomerohedrally twinned, given the very similar a and c axes (14.3288(9) and 14.3563(10) Å) with β close to 90° (91.296(6)°), thus requiring a TWIN command interchanging a and c. The framework adopts the (4.62)3(42.610.83) rutile (rtl) topology with all 5-hip are 3-connected and Zn2 nodes 6-connected.

elements.content: Compound 3 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Cmc21 with an asymmetric unit consisting of four zinc atoms, two triply deprotonated 5-hip ligands, two-and-a-half doubly deprotonated H-5-hip ligands, two tetramethylammonium ([Me4N+]) cations, and one [Me2NH2 +] cation (Figure ). Once again, the same SBU is seen in both Zn dimers, but this time with an additional carboxylate bridge. Zn1 and Zn2 are pentacoordinated by oxygen, and Zn3 and Zn4 are hexacoordinated.

elements.content: As with 1 and 2, the hip ligands bridge the Zn atoms to form a three-dimensional framework (Figure ) with substantial void spaces centered at (0, 1/2, 1/2) and (1/2, 1/2, 1/2), each with a volume of 1968 Å3 and a total of 1000 electrons per cell in these two voids, corresponding to 50 DMF molecules per unit cell or 3.125 per Zn atom.

elements.content: Given the overall poor statistics of the structure solution of 3 due to intractably twinned crystals, we have rounded this to three DMF per unit cell, which can be seen from Fourier difference plots, although again being unstable to refinement. This void forms a channel in the b- and c-axes centered at a = 0 and 1/2. This gives a structure consisting of dense layers of Zn, H-5-hip, 5-hip, Me4N, and Me2NH2 bridged through a further H-5-hip in the a-axes to link the layers across the void spaces. This framework is the first record of the (4.52)2(42.52.67.74)(42.53.63.7.8) topology as far as we are aware and consists of 5- and 6-connected dimers and four distinct ligand binding modes (two linear; two trigonal) (Figure ).

elements.content: The thin blade-like crystal morphology of 3, coupled with its numerous stacking faults, presented substantial difficulties to structural solution, and despite repeated attempts, a single crystal could not be found and integration of the twinned data appeared ineffective. To further complicate matters, the determination of the crystal system and cell was difficult with two possible solutions, of which we chose orthorhombic with a large a-axis because this presented the smaller asymmetric unit and higher symmetry. In the monoclinic setting, there was clearly an additional symmetry element in the ASU that could not be incorporated into any monoclinic space group. Despite these difficulties, the basic framework structure was clear (Figures and ) from the solution obtained, allowing us to compare this MOF to other members of this family.

elements.content: Compound 4 was synthesized from the same solution as compound 2 but at 130 °C to produce the same (4.62)2(42.69.84) apo framework as reported by Sun et al. for which we present a different interpretation. While the framework remains the same, we note the presence of two [Me2NH2 +] cations in the void, one of which is disordered, producing a charge-balanced framework (Figure ), also containing the same SBU as compounds 1–3. SQUEEZE analysis indicates that there are two voids centered at (1/2, 0, 0) and (1/2, 1/2, 1/2), each with an electron count of 30 (Figure ). The analysis is somewhat complicated by the presence of the disordered cations and is likely to contain two molecules of DMF per unit cell or half per formula unit.

elements.content: All four of the compounds are effectively nonporous after activation by exchange with clean DMF and CH2Cl2 and heating under vacuum at either 20 or 100 °C. All four compounds become opaque on solvent exchange with CH2Cl2, indicating that the DMF is displaced. PXRD analysis (ESI) indicates that 1–3 retain their structures, although in the case of 1 with some degradation of crystal quality. For 1–3, the TGA trace (ESI) shows that it is possible to remove DMF solvent by heating without decomposition of the material, consistent with the PXRD data.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stability and Porosity Measurements

All four of the compounds are effectively nonporous after activation by exchange with clean DMF and CH2Cl2 and heating under vacuum at either 20 or 100 °C. All four compounds become opaque on solvent exchange with CH2Cl2, indicating that the DMF is displaced. PXRD analysis (ESI) indicates that 1-3 retain their structures, although in the case of 1 with some degradation of crystal quality. For 1-3, the TGA trace (ESI) shows that it is possible to remove DMF solvent by heating without decomposition of the material, consistent with the PXRD data.

elements.content:
All three compounds display an absorbance at 309 nm, in common with H3-5-hip in the solid state and in 10–5 M DMF solution (Figure ).

Fluorometry

H3-5-hip in the solid state shows an intense purple emission centered at 360 nm (λex = 340 nm, Figure S18, ). Compound 2 shows an emission at 379 nm (λex = 340 nm, Figure S20, ). Compound 3 shows two emission peaks at 345 and 360 nm (λex = 325 nm, Figure S21, ). Compound 1, however, shows no detectable fluorescence (Figure ). Compound 4 is discussed in detail in ref .

elements.content: The synthetic conditions under which this series of compounds is prepared is highly sensitive to the presence of small molecule additives and their concentration (Scheme ). There is increasing interest in the role of templates in MOF formation as routes to new structural motifs, and the role of template can be played by structural and nonstructural components and solvents.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

The synthetic conditions under which this series of compounds is prepared is highly sensitive to the presence of small molecule additives and their concentration (Scheme ). There is increasing interest in the role of templates in MOF formation as routes to new structural motifs, and the role of template can be played by structural and nonstructural components and solvents.

elements.clean_text: 3  Additives and Their Outcomes

elements.content: While Me3NH+ is not incorporated into the structure of 1, its presence is vital to forming this phase in any degree of purity, but the amount present must be within a narrow range of Zn/Me3NHCl molar ratio 1:0.1–1:0.9. Outside of this range no crystals of 1 are observed. This would imply that the [Me3NH+] cation plays a transitory yet significant role in the formation of the structure, probably through hydrogen bonding to the nucleating [Zn2(5-hip)] clusters. The presence of NH4Cl or MeNH3Cl only resulted in solutions across the concentration ranges tested, indicating that a cation merely hydrogen bonding to the nucleating cluster is not enough to template 1. Compound 1 also relies on a small amount of water being present: fresh DMF produces a dark solution on heating with the reactants for 1, and an insoluble gum forms quickly. Leaving the reaction mixture uncovered overnight to allow fresh DMF to absorb water from the air resulted only in solutions, indicating too high a water content. On the other hand, controlled addition of 5 μL of water per milliliter of DMF employed produces the optimal conditions for the synthesis of 1, precluding the formation of the gum and ensuring maximum yield.

Outside of this range no crystals of 1 are observed. This would imply that the [Me3NH+] cation plays a transitory yet significant role in the formation of the structure, probably through hydrogen bonding to the nucleating [Zn2(5-hip)] clusters. The presence of NH4Cl or MeNH3Cl only resulted in solutions across the concentration ranges tested, indicating that a cation merely hydrogen bonding to the nucleating cluster is not enough to template 1. Compound 1 also relies on a small amount of water being present: fresh DMF produces a dark solution on heating with the reactants for 1, and an insoluble gum forms quickly. Leaving the reaction mixture uncovered overnight to allow fresh DMF to absorb water from the air resulted only in solutions, indicating too high a water content. On the other hand, controlled addition of 5 μL of water per milliliter of DMF employed produces the optimal conditions for the synthesis of 1, precluding the formation of the gum and ensuring maximum yield.

elements.content: In compound 2, water is the key additive. If the reaction is run without any additional water other than that present in Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, then a darkening of the solution occurs on heating followed by a black gum forming. As little as 10 μL of H2O per milliliter of DMF begins to lighten the solution, and by 30 μL/mL, 2 begins to form. In both 1 and 2, the water present is involved in the slow decomposition of DMF and provides the hydroxide necessary to deprotonate the H3-5-hip at a rate to allow crystal formation. This DMF decomposition also provides the [Me2NH2 +] cation present in both MOFs. When the reaction is run with water as the only additive, a small amount of 1 is formed. When 15 μL of pyridine/mL of DMF is added, the fraction of 1 is reduced, indicating that base may be the determining factor in producing 2 in favor of 1 despite the same components being present in both reaction mixtures.

When 15 μL of pyridine/mL of DMF is added, the fraction of 1 is reduced, indicating that base may be the determining factor in producing 2 in favor of 1 despite the same components being present in both reaction mixtures.

elements.content: Compound 3 also shows a concentration-dependent additive effect on phase production with the optimal ratio of Zn/[Me4N+] being 1:1. No water is required to form 3 unless the DMF is freshly opened, the necessary water to prevent darkening and to produce the [Me2NH2 +] cation from DMF being provided in this case by the water of crystallization in Zn(NO3)2·6H2O.

No water is required to form 3 unless the DMF is freshly opened, the necessary water to prevent darkening and to produce the [Me2NH2 +] cation from DMF being provided in this case by the water of crystallization in Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O.

elements.content: The dependency on water of the synthesis of 1–3 is not uncommon in MOFs because the hydrolysis of alkylformamide solvents is often a critical step in the formation of the SBU (e.g., the base formed by DMF decomposition providing the central oxygen atoms in the [Zn4O] cluster in MOF-5), in the deprotonation of carboxylic acids, or in the production of dialkylammonium cations. All three processes occur in 1–4 from deprotonation of the phenolic protons in formation of the SBU, deprotonation of the carboxylates, and the production of the dimethylammonium cations.

All three processes occur in 1-4 from deprotonation of the phenolic protons in formation of the SBU, deprotonation of the carboxylates, and the production of the dimethylammonium cations.

elements.content: In addition to the cation- and neutral-species induced structural control, an anion-induced structure has been reported where sulfate is incorporated into a Zn/5-hip/Me2NH2 + MOF, although no properties other than the structure are reported.

elements.content: Because the single crystal character of 1–3 is lost on activation, it is difficult to determine the reasons for the lack of porosity, although increased thermal motion of the alkylammonium cations may be responsible for obstructing access to the pores.

elements.content: The fluorescent properties of these compounds originate from the 5-hydroxyisophthalate ligand and show slight modification on coordination to the Zn atoms. The relatively small shift in peak fluorescence in 2 and 3 is likely due to the compounds having essentially similar local structures. A larger shift would reasonably be expected if the SBU were to change, and such modifications can be seen in a range of zinc MOFs constructed from 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate where the addition of different cations to the MOF result in different coordination and a tuning of the fluorescence from blue to red on increasing coordination number from the ligand on the metal.

elements.content: The 5-hip ligand appears in a number of MOFs, coordination polymers, metal–organic polyhedra, and supramolecular species. There are a number of homoleptic 5-hip MOFs, but most contain a secondary ligand. The hydroxyl group of 5-hip also allows for alkylation or phenylation to occur at that site to add additional coordinating or chelating groups to increase the range of structures possible. There are relatively few 5-hip MOFs where both carboxylates and hydroxyl groups coordinate to build a 3-D network, and the series of compounds presented here substantially expands the number of homoleptic 5-hip MOFs. Each of the three compounds shares some structural features, particularly the Ph–O–(Zn2)–OOC–Ph SBU from Scheme . While this SBU is commonly seen in dimeric and polynuclear species, very few MOFs were found in the CSD (version 5.35, Nov. 2013 and updates) with this motif. {[Zn2(H2dht)(dht)0.5(azpy)0.5 (H2O)]·4 H2O} (H2dht = dihydroxyterphthalate, azpy = 4,4′-azobipyridine) is a particular example of a fluorescent MOF with this SBU. A polymerized form of this SBU can be seen in MOF-71/MIL-47 where the remaining coordination sites on the metal dimers also form the same SBU.

While this SBU is commonly seen in dimeric and polynuclear species, very few MOFs were found in the CSD (version 5.35, Nov. 2013 and updates) with this motif. {[Zn2(H2dht)(dht)0.5(azpy)0.5 (H2O)]⋅4 H2O} (H2dht = dihydroxyterphthalate, azpy = 4,4'-azobipyridine) is a particular example of a fluorescent MOF with this SBU. A polymerized form of this SBU can be seen in MOF-71/MIL-47 where the remaining coordination sites on the metal dimers also form the same SBU.

elements.content: Through careful control of the presence of additives, we have expanded the range of zinc MOFs with 5-hydroxyisophthalate, an inexpensive reagent with high coordination potential, each with the same uncommon SBU. The fluorescence properties of each MOF are determined by the presence of coordinated solvent. While these MOFs are effectively nonporous under standard activation conditions, this work illustrates the sensitive nature of MOF synthesis to reactant solution components in determining the resultant structure.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Through careful control of the presence of additives, we have expanded the range of zinc MOFs with 5-hydroxyisophthalate, an inexpensive reagent with high coordination potential, each with the same uncommon SBU. The fluorescence properties of each MOF are determined by the presence of coordinated solvent. While these MOFs are effectively nonporous under standard activation conditions, this work illustrates the sensitive nature of MOF synthesis to reactant solution components in determining the resultant structure.

cln_elements.content:
DMF solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (4.0 mL, 0.1 M), DMF solution of H3-5-hip (4.0 mL, 0.1 M), and DMF solution of Me3NHCl (2.0 mL, 0.1 M) with 5 μL of H2O added per milliliter of DMF were heated to 120 °C in a scintillation vial for 72 h. Pale yellow block crystals of 1 were formed with a yield of 25 mg (16% relative to Zn).

Synthesis of α-[Me<sub>2</sub>NH<sub>2</sub>]<sub>2</sub>[Zn<sub>2</sub>(5-hip)<sub>2</sub>]·2DMF, <bold>2</bold>

DMF solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (4.0 mL, 0.1 M), DMF solution of H3-5-hip (4.0 mL, 0.1 M), 60 μL (0.77 mmol) of pyridine, and 300 μL of distilled water (16.67 mmol) were heated as above, yielding 119 mg of yellow block crystals (82% relative to Zn). Synthesis without pyridine produces 116 mg of 2 but with a small impurity fraction of 1.

Synthesis of [Me<sub>2</sub>NH<sub>2</sub>][Me<sub>4</sub>N]<sub>2</sub>[Zn<sub>4</sub>(5-hip)<sub>2</sub>(H-5-hip<sub>2.5</sub>)]·3DMF, <bold>3</bold>

DMF solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (4.0 mL, 0.1 M), DMF solution of H3-5-hip (4.0 mL, 0.1 M), and 44 mg (4.0 mmol) of Me4NCl were heated to 120 °C in a scintillation vial for 72 h to yield “sea-urchin-like” clusters of yellow plate needles of 3. Yield 89 mg (60% relative to Zn).

DMF solution of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (4.0 mL, 0.1 M), DMF solution of H3-5-hip (4.0 mL, 0.1 M), and DMF solution of Me3NHCl (2.0 mL, 0.1 M) with 5 μL of H2O added per milliliter of DMF were heated to 120 °C in a scintillation vial for 72 h. Pale yellow block crystals of 1 were formed with a yield of 25 mg (16% relative to Zn).

Synthesis of α-[Me2NH2]2[Zn2(5-hip)2]⋅2DMF, 2 

DMF solution of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (4.0 mL, 0.1 M), DMF solution of H3-5-hip (4.0 mL, 0.1 M), 60 μL (0.77 mmol) of pyridine, and 300 μL of distilled water (16.67 mmol) were heated as above, yielding 119 mg of yellow block crystals (82% relative to Zn). Synthesis without pyridine produces 116 mg of 2 but with a small impurity fraction of 1.

Synthesis of [Me2NH2][Me4N]2[Zn4(5-hip)2(H-5-hip2.5)]⋅3DMF, 3 

DMF solution of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (4.0 mL, 0.1 M), DMF solution of H3-5-hip (4.0 mL, 0.1 M), and 44 mg (4.0 mmol) of Me4NCl were heated to 120 °C in a scintillation vial for 72 h to yield "sea-urchin-like" clusters of yellow plate needles of 3. Yield 89 mg (60% relative to Zn).

cln_elements.content:
As with 1 and 2, the hip ligands bridge the Zn atoms to form a three-dimensional framework (Figure ) with substantial void spaces centered at (0, 1/2, 1/2) and (1/2, 1/2, 1/2), each with a volume of 1968 Å3 and a total of 1000 electrons per cell in these two voids, corresponding to 50 DMF molecules per unit cell or 3.125 per Zn atom.

Spectroscopic PropertiesUV–Vis

All three compounds display an absorbance at 309 nm, in common with H3-5-hip in the solid state and in 10–5 M DMF solution (Figure ).

Fluorometry

H3-5-hip in the solid state shows an intense purple emission centered at 360 nm (λex = 340 nm, Figure S18, ). Compound 2 shows an emission at 379 nm (λex = 340 nm, Figure S20, ). Compound 3 shows two emission peaks at 345 and 360 nm (λex = 325 nm, Figure S21, ). Compound 1, however, shows no detectable fluorescence (Figure ). Compound 4 is discussed in detail in ref .
